column4: Firefox can't resolve DNS (although it seems that some other apps - like ping - can) and ifup says that the interface eth0 is unknown.  ifconfig reports that eth0 exists, however.
if the interface exists and no ip is attached to it, and no default route is set, and your /etc/resolv.conf doesn't have any dns servers, then yes, firefox is operating as it should
resolv.conf does indeed have dns nameservers.
can you ping them?
yes.  I can also view some sites by domain name, but only after I load them by IP.
what happens if you click on the 'try again' button a few times?
same deal.
are the dns servers local or from your isp?
local.  i've also tried using OpenDNS, to no avail.  for the record, none of the other machines on the network have this issue.
i have no idea how your network is setup. try using non-local dns servers.
like openDNS?  already said, makes no difference.
i'm sure that verizon has their own set of dns servers for its paying customers to use
while I'm sure they do, the fact that changing the DNS servers to an outside service (without success) indicates to me that the issue lies elsewhere.
could be a firewall on your end or a faulty ethernet cable
what happens if you connect the machine directly to the dsl modem?
the situation is unchanged with the machine connected directly to the router.
how long as the machine been doing this? just recently or the whole time?
the machine has been doing this since i distupgraded last night.
what did you distupgrade from/to?
then you should inquire in #ubuntu+1, we don't support intrepid here quite as well yet
the problem is clearly with intrepid, though.
support for my hardware (forceware integrated ethernet) isn't on the list of (known) issues.  and in any case, a networking problem still ought to be solvable by reasonable methods.
i've already explained the support position, and i really don't know much about intrepid right now. just trying to help you get your problem solved. :)

After a lot of swearing/hair-pulling/violence, I determined it's a kernel issue (& is already reported in Launchpad.)  Anyone else asks, the solution is to reboot back into 2.6.24 and then everything's ducky again.  :)
